channel.title: Comments on: Display CAL and C# code of a object in RTC

item.title: By: jaspreet
item.dc:creator: jaspreet
item.description: Yeah and this can also help us to check code of objects from published extensions which are not visible in Developer Enviroment.
item.content:encoded: Yeah and this can also help us to check code of objects from published extensions which are not visible in Developer Enviroment.

item.title: By: Dadi Karason
item.dc:creator: Dadi Karason
item.description: Nice. I knew you could access the C# code from the %programdata%\Microsoft folders but this is more convenient.
item.content:encoded: Nice. I knew you could access the C# code from the %programdata%\Microsoft folders but this is more convenient.

item.title: By: View code of Extension Objects in RTC – Jaspreet Singh
item.dc:creator: View code of Extension Objects in RTC – Jaspreet Singh
item.description: […] If you have some experience working with NAV extensions, you would know that once an extension is installed for a tenant you cannot see the objects in Developer environment. NAV stores these objects in table 2000000150 (Nav App Object Metadata). Using the way from my previous blog, I was able to modify the page from that blog to also show objects of extensions. Check it out here. […]
item.content:encoded: […] If you have some experience working with NAV extensions, you would know that once an extension is installed for a tenant you cannot see the objects in Developer environment. NAV stores these objects in table 2000000150 (Nav App Object Metadata). Using the way from my previous blog, I was able to modify the page from that blog to also show objects of extensions. Check it out here. […]
